Legal_Issue: Was the Visa Officer's decision to reject the applicant's permanent residence application based on a negative substituted evaluation reasonable and procedurally fair?
Governing_Law: s. 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant met the point threshold but had concerns regarding labor market integration
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility; officer bears burden of justification for negative discretion
Legal_Rule: An officer may substitute their evaluation if points awarded do not sufficiently indicate economic establishment in Canada; procedural fairness requires informing applicants of negative discretion
Procedural_Issue: Failure to inform applicant of negative substituted evaluation during interview
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer's decision found unreasonable due to procedural unfairness
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Breach occurred as applicant was not informed of negative substituted evaluation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Point threshold met, labor market integration concerns
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged the reasonableness and fairness of the rejection
Court_Result: Judicial review allowed; case remitted to a different officer
Legal_Rule_Source: s. 76(3), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application forms, officer notes
Outcome: Case remitted to a different officer for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of decision and referral for redetermination
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient economic establishment despite meeting point threshold
Applicable_Process: Permanent residence application under economic class
Governing_Rule: s. 76(3), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
